info.title: Generic Messaging API
info.description: This is a pilot project for implementing ISA2 messaging REST API

get.summary: DSD Mock: Message Reference List Endpoint
get.description: This endpoint returns a list of message references available for pulling, following the Message Reference schema.

value.title: No final recipient configured for the pulling user

404.description: Sent when no message is found that maps to the pull request

value.title: No Message Found
value.detail: Sent when no message is found that maps to the pull request

401.description: Sent when the pull request is unauthorized

value.title: Unauthorized
value.detail: Sent when the pull request is unauthorized

MessageReferenceList.title: A Message Reference object defined by the ISAÂ² IPS REST API Messaging API Specification
MessageReferenceList.description: A Message Reference object to be used when multiple messages could be retrieved from an API operation

MessageReference.title: A Message Reference object defined by the ISAÂ² IPS REST API Messaging API Specification

messageId.description: The unique identifier of the message.

service.description: A representation of the service the message is submitted to.

action.description: A representation of the action related to the service the message is submitted to.

href.description: The direct link for getting the specific message

MessageReference.description: A Message Reference object to be used when multiple messages could be retrieved from an API operation

jws-compact-detached.title: The message-level and payload signature
jws-compact-detached.description: The JWS compact representation schema defines the string pattern as a regular expression, denoting the structure a JWS compact token MUST follow to be a valid compact JWS Representation. It is used for defining the value of the message-level signature and of the payload signature

Problem.title: A Problem Details object (RFC 7807) defined by the ISAÂ² IPS REST API Core Profile

title.description: A short summary of the problem type, written in English and readable for engineers (usually not suited for non technical stakeholders and not localized).

type.description: An URI reference that identifies the problem type. When dereferenced, it SHOULD provide human-readable documentation for the problem type (e.g. using HTML).

status.description: The HTTP status code generated by the origin server for this occurrence of the problem.

detail.description: A human-readable explanation specific to this occurrence of the problem.

instance.description: A URI reference that identifies the specific occurrence of the problem. It may or may not yield further information if dereferenced.

Problem.description: A Problem Details object (RFC 7807) with ISAÂ² IPS REST API extensions, used for signals (responses) to messages

jws-compact.title: JWT token.
jws-compact.description: The JWS compact representation schema defines the string pattern as a regular expression, denoting the structure a JWS compact token MUST follow to be a valid compact JWS Representation. It is used for defining the value of the Original-Sender token.

OrganizationQuery.title: Organization query request

name.title: Partial country name
name.description: Parameter is used for name search

limit.title: Result count limit
limit.description: The number of resources of a collection to be returned from a request. The limit MUST be a positive integer

offset.title: Offset of results
offset.description: The offset the response should start providing resources of the collection. It MUST be a positive integer

sort.title: Sort the records
sort.description: Used to express the sorting order of resources in a collection. It MUST follow the following regular expression: (-|+)<field-name> (',' (-|+)<field-name>)*

OrganizationQuery.description: Object contains search parameters to retrieve organization list

SignalMessage.title: A Signal message which extends Problem object (RFC 7807) defined by the ISAÂ² IPS REST API Core Profile

title.description: A short summary of the problem type, written in English and readable for engineers (usually not suited for non technical stakeholders and not localized).

type.description: An URI reference that identifies the problem type. When dereferenced, it SHOULD provide human-readable documentation for the problem type (e.g. using HTML).

status.description: The HTTP status code generated by the origin server for this occurrence of the problem.

detail.description: A human-readable explanation specific to this occurrence of the problem.

instance.description: A URI reference that identifies the specific occurrence of the problem. It may or may not yield further information if dereferenced.

digest.description: The digest of the received message using the notation proposed in 'Digest Header' (https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-httpbis-digest-headers).

SignalMessage.description: A Signal message which extends Problem object (RFC 7807) defined by the ISAÂ² IPS REST API Core Profile

messageId.name: messageId
messageId.description: The MessageId is the unique identifier of the message submitted. It MUST be defined by the client. It is used for reliable messaging for guaranteeing the at-most-once message submission (no duplicate message-ids are allowed by the server implementing the API).

rMessageId.name: rMessageId
rMessageId.description: The identifier of the response message being submitted. It MUST be generated by the client submitting the response message.

Original-Sender.name: Original-Sender
Original-Sender.description: The Original Sender represents the authenticated entity acting as the user that sends the message using the client. Following the API Core Profile, the original sender MUST be represented with an OpenID Connect token, in the form of Compact JWT Token.

Final-Recipient.name: Final-Recipient
Final-Recipient.description: The Final Recipient is the entity for whom the message is sent. Can be a single identifier or a set of identifiers, as described in the Recipient Addressing Schemes section of the specification. The representation of the final recipient is out of scope of the current specification.

Timestamp.name: Timestamp
Timestamp.description: The Timestamp is the exact date and time at which the message was sent. It is provided by the client and verified by the server.

Edel-Message-Sig.name: Edel-Message-Sig
Edel-Message-Sig.description: The Edel-Message-Sig carries the signature of the HTTP Message following the API Core Profile on Message-Level Security. Following the light context constraints, the signature is optional for the client messages, but is RECOMMENDED for server messages.

The Edel-Message-Sig carries the signature of the HTTP Message following the API Core Profile on Message-Level Security. Following the light context constraints, the signature is optional for the client messages, but is RECOMMENDED for server messages.

Edel-Payload-Sig.description: The Edel-Payload-Sig carries the signature of a subpart of the Multipart message (see User Message section) following the API Core Profile on Payload Security.

Original-Sender.description: The Original Sender represents the authenticated entity acting as the user that sends the message using the client. Following the API Core Profile, the original sender MUST be represented with an OpenID Connect token, in the form of Compact JWT Token.

Final-Recipient.description: The Final Recipient is the entity for whom the message is sent. Can be a single identifier or a set of identifiers, as described in the Recipient Addressing Schemes section of the specification. The representation of the final recipient is out of scope of the current specification.

Timestamp.description: The Timestamp is the exact date and time at which the message was sent. It is provided by the client and verified by the server.

DSD_ClientCredentials_OAuthSecurity.description:
Client Credentials authorization between National Broker and DSD using OKTA authorization server.

Important Note:OKTA Oauth server does not allow client credentials authorization from web browser like when using Swagger UI. When testing the services with Swagger UI, use DSD_Http_BearerTokenAuthorization to provide an access token that has been obtained previously outside of Swagger UI.

DSD_Http_BearerTokenAuthorization.description:
OKTA OAuth server does not allow client credentials authorization from web browser. Hence providing Bearer Token Authorization for use in **Swagger UI**.

**Note:** this is only a workaround for a limitation of using Swagger UI. For system integration please use **DSD_ClientCredentials_OAuthSecurity** .

**Usage:** Submit an HTTPS POST request to the token url of **DSD_ClientCredentials_OAuthSecurity** with body contents **grant_type=client_credentials** and **scope=ROLE_DSD** in **x-www-form-encoded** format. As HTTP basic authorization send the **Client ID** and **Client Secret** of the National Broker. The OKTA server will return a JSON response containing an access token as a JWT.Submit the JWT in this **DSD_Http_BearerTokenAuthorization**.
